awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Force And Impedance-Based Exoskeleton Robots For Seamless Assistance And Neurologically Sound Rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader societal impact/commercial potential of this project centers on improving rehabilitation outcomes for individuals suffering from motor dysfunction due to stroke, spinal cord injury, and other conditions. In the US alone, there are 600,000 new stroke patients each year who rely on conventional one-on-one therapies for recovery. Due to cost and labor limitations they do not receive consistent, frequent, and intensive training needed for full recovery and optimal quality of life. As a result, stroke care guidelines recommend robotic rehabilitation in all care settings. Providing robotic rehabilitation using the proposed exoskeleton robots is a compelling solution for hospitals, rehabilitation centers, and senior living communities. In addition to providing frequent and intensive therapy, the devices can accurately measure patient progress and performance for personalized care. The exoskeletons are also a powerful research tool into effective rehabilitation methods and have the potential to transform the manufacturing sector by providing a solution for industrial processes that are too complex for full automation and too physically demanding for humans. The proposed exoskeleton devices reduce the risk of injury from accidents and overexertion for individuals performing repetitive, high-stress tasks. Additional results include increased productivity and decreased absenteeism and turn-over.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project advances the development of exoskeleton robots targeted at rehabilitation. A substantial portion of the US population requires intensive rehabilitation services for neuromuscular impairment. Robotic rehabilitation has attracted attention due to the potential for better patient outcomes. Current robotic solutions lack the anatomical mobility and compliant dynamic behavior to produce neurologically-sound therapeutic behaviors. The proposed project addresses these deficits and will result in exoskeleton robots capable of essential advanced rehabilitation behaviors. During the Phase I project, a high-performance, force-controlled actuator was developed and will be the core component enabling the desired behavior. In this project, the physical structures and control algorithms of the exoskeletons will be designed and built with a focus on dynamic transparency and kinematic compatibility with the human body to capitalize on the capabilities of the actuator. Additionally, the control software will use feedback loops and a visually interactive environment with performance metrics to keep patients engaged.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Executive Summary

Through the support of NSF SBIR(award #: 1853183), Roboligent has made significant achievements and contributions by developing and commercializing a cutting-edge force-control compliant robot arm. The primary objective was to facilitate safe and effective automation in the context of emerging AI-based applications, including human-robot interactions, robotic rehabilitation, and logistics automation.

Phase I Achievements

During Phase I of the project, precision torque-controlled actuators were developed as a foundational component. These actuators served as the building blocks for a groundbreaking collaborative robot manipulator. This manipulator, designed to operate based on impedance behaviors, aligns with the evolving requirements of service automation.

Phase II Milestones

In Phase II, Roboligent successfully completed the development of a pioneering precision force-control manipulator. This manipulator consistently operates in impedance mode, setting it apart from any existing robotic manipulator on the market. The development encompassed hardware design, prototyping, control software programming, and the demonstration of various applications.

The manipulator is purpose-built for human-robot interaction and AI-driven service automation, offering an exceptional level of precision and compliance. Its ability to execute accurate motions in a highly compliant mode ensures exceptionally smooth and safe movements, positioning it as an ideal solution for a wide range of applications.

Optimo: A Clinical Breakthrough

Leveraging the Optimo manipulator, Roboligent has successfully developed the commercial version of a physical therapy automation robot, named Optimo Regen (OR). OR is poised for clinical use and evaluation studies, featuring:

  • Neurologically-sound physical therapy exercises.

  • Versatile usability across multiple body segments.

  • Productivity-oriented advanced features.

OR fills a critical niche by providing upper and lower extremity exercises, including gait training, at the cost of a single-device solution. The exceptional clinical outcomes observed during its validation phase, particularly in stroke patient physical therapy, underscore its potential to transform the field.

Clinical Impact and Validation

Optimo Regen has garnered significant attention from clinical groups due to its outstanding clinical results in pilot studies. For instance, chronic stroke patients exhibited noticeable improvements in walking performance after just one 15-minute gait training session with Optimo Regen. Acute stroke patients have experienced substantial upper limb mobility recovery after a mere 10 days of robotic therapy sessions.

Future Prospects

The force-control robot technology developed through this NSF SBIR project has the potential to revolutionize daily work and life by enhancing the productivity of human activities. Notably, the physical therapy automation solution promises to improve clinical outcomes while reducing overall healthcare costs in the field of physical rehabilitation.

In conclusion, the Roboligent project has achieved significant milestones in the development of force-control robot technology, leading to the creation of Optimo Regen, a groundbreaking physical therapy automation robot with profound clinical implications. These innovations hold promise for both the advancement of automation and the enhancement of healthcare outcomes.


Last Modified: 09/15/2023
Modified by: Bongsu Kim

Image
  • Optimo Regen is a multi-modal physical therapy automation system that provides a wide range of exercises for both upper and lower extremities, including gait training. The photo illustrates a gait training session with Optimo Regen for stroke patients.
    Roboligent, Inc.
    Copyrighted
    Bongsu Kim
    Optimo Regen: Next-gen physical therapy automation
